page.title: 01Inchkeith
page.content: "L'ile des Chevaux" - "Islandd of Horses" - was the name given to Inchkeith by the French troops garrisoned there in the mid 1500's because their horses thrived on the grass. Mary of Guise visiting the island, also had her own name for it - "L'ile Dieu" - "Gods Island". The names are romantic, as is the history of this rock which is situated in the Firth of Forth between the Fife town of Kinghorn (into which parish the island falls) and the port of Leith. It stands at a height of about 55m above sea level at its highest point, where a lighthouse is perched, and is approximately 1500m (1mile) long and, on average, 450m (1/4mile).
